title: 7 Best Dining Tables for Small Spaces (2025): AD-Approved Picks
author: Yelena Moroz Alpert
excerpt: The best dining tables for small spaces don’t have to sacrifice anything in the charm department. Here, several editor-approved picks in several styles

html:
All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links.

Featured in this article

Even if you don’t live in palatial quarters, the best dining tables for small spaces can make quite the impact regardless of your home’s cramped footprint.

After all, limited square footage should never get in the way of gathering people you love, working someplace other than your bed, or hosting a game night. A simple round table with a flattering shape is a great place to start. To elevate the look, Los Angeles–based Breegan Jane recommends adding multifunctional seating that’s foldable or “can easily be tucked away underneath the table when not in use.” If you’re keen on showing a little personality, consider a statement chair that can serve as an office chair, dining chair, and extra seating for entertaining.

Catherine Branstetter, an interior decorator based in Nashville, recommends tackling the challenge of close quarters from an emotional angle. She suggests a table that “allows for easy conversation and one that has comfortable chairs around it that you can sit in for hours.” Jane, an interior designer often seen on HGTV, takes a pragmatic approach. “Functionality is also something to keep in mind,” she says. “A very heavy piece may be hard to move around, which you might need to do if your small space needs to be multipurpose.”

Here, seven of our favorite picks for dining tables that are perfect for small spaces—whether that’s a first apartment, a cozy breakfast nook, or city living with a teeny kitchen.

  • Best for Squeezing in Several People

    1/7

    Allmodern Aava Dining Table

    The Aava dining table may look like it’s immobile, but it actually weighs less than 100 pounds. With a strong angular design, it aims to make a statement and can fit up to six when the butterfly leaf is expanded (otherwise four people can fit comfortably around it.) While assembly is required, customers say it is relatively easy and quick. Plus it ships quickly, should you need one for a last-minute housewarming party.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 53.9"H x 53.9"W x 31.5"D
    • Materials: Manufactured wood

    Upsides

    • Extendable
    • 4 color options
    • Budget-friendly

    Downsides

    • Assembly required

  • Best Moody Dining Table

    2/7

    Mermelada Estudio Lola Dining Table

    For those enamored by the Brutalist movement but not ready to take the plunge, consider the CB2 Mermelada Estudio Lola concrete dining table. The silhouette is sleek and unpretentious but still has a a certain gravitas in your dining space. And since it comes in black and ivory, you can decide if you want to go with something more stark or airy in tone. Total small-space brilliance.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 31.5"H x 45"W
    • Materials: Stone powder, cement, and natural fiber

    Upsides

    • Black and ivory colorways
    • Sleek silhouette

    Downsides

    • Color may fade over time due to the natural characteristics of concrete
    • Hairline cracks may appear; will not affect structural integrity

  • Best Drop Leaf Design

    3/7

    Pottery Barn Mateo Dining Table

    Versatility is the name of the game in the case of this Pottery Barn Mateo drop leaf dining table. “Flexibility is key for a small dining table. As we have learned over the past two-plus years, a dining table can function as a workstation, homework spot, or a place to entertain and play games—all in one day!” says Britt Zunino of Studio DB. Tuck this table against a wall, a small-space tip from Sara Cukerbaum of SLIC Design, to keep the table out of the flow of traffic.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 30"H (two leaves) x 30"W x 54"L
    • Materials: Solid poplar wood, poplar veneers, beech wood, and MDF

    Upsides

    • Kiln-dried wood
    • Two sizes
    • Affordable

    Downsides

    • Doorstep delivery requires assembly

  • Best for Farmhouse Charm

    4/7

    McGee & Co. Newbold Dining Table

    “I’m a big fan of round tables,” Branstetter says. “Not only are they the best for good conversation, but they’re also great for seating as many around the table as possible, and easy to walk around.” This rustic farmhouse style from McGee & Co. feels like a conversation piece all on its own—especially since the geometric base juxtaposes the curves of the top.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 30"H x 60"W
    • Materials: Honey oak veneer, solid oak, & engineered hardwood

    Upsides

    • Architectural frame
    • Solid oak

    Downsides

    • Price
    • Assembly required

  • Best Cafe Table

    5/7

    West Elm Chroma Restaurant Table

    Even if you don’t own a pied-à-terre, the West Elm Chroma is a type of table that evokes the vibe. The minimalist silhouette comes in eight colorways—from dusty blush to sapphire—that adds just enough punch without stealing the show from your dining space decor. Pair it with an upholstered chair in sumptuous fabric for a play on materials that keeps the design looking too industrial.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 29.4"H x 36"W
    • Materials: Tempered glass tabletop over engineered wood, powder-coated iron base and stem.

    Upsides

    • Customizable colorways
    • 30” and 36” size options
    • Crafted in a Fair Trade Certified facility

    Downsides

    • Only Haze and Dark Olive finished tables are stocked. All other finish options are made to order.

  • Best for Bauhaus Design

    6/7

    Schoolhouse Forma Dining Table

    When it comes to Schoolhouse Forma style, it is all in the rounded corners. “While shape matters a lot, I find that the most important thing when selecting a table for a smaller space is for the table to have rounded edges. It creates a much softer look,” explains New York City–based interior designer Nicole Cohen. This Bauhaus-inspired table has five color options for the base to suit any decor—a small-space dream come true.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 29"H x 36"W, 60"L
    • Materials: Powder-coated steel, plywood, and oak veneer

    Upsides

    • Customizable colors for base
    • Affordable

    Downsides

    • Assembly required

  • Best for Material Options

    7/7

    Room & Board Aria Dining Table

    Colson Horton, an interior designer and stylist in Nashville, loves a glass tabletop for a small space. It’s easy to see why. “In a small space, take advantage of a table with a unique-shaped base or texture to add character to the room, such as one with a tamboured wood base or a colorful marble with a glass top,” Colson advises. The Room&Board Aria model is customization at its best. Not only can you select the glass top (it comes in wood finishes too) but the powder-coated steel base comes in nine hues. This style comes in a petite 27-inch diameter top and goes up to 60 inches. With such a size range, your dining room should never feel crowded.

    Specs

    • Dimensions: 29"H x 42"W
    • Materials: Glass top, powder-coated steel base

    Upsides

    • Multiple sizes for top diameter (27” to 60”)
    • Customizable top and base
    • Three glass top options (white, satin etched, smoke)

    Downsides

    • Assembly required
